awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of near-surface eastward flows in the South Indian Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
Objectives and intellectual Merit: A remarkable aspect of the upper-ocean circulation in the tropical and subtropical South Indian Ocean (SIO) is the presence of near-surface, eastward flow across the basin, which often appears as a set of distinct currents and jets. These currents have been detected in observations and simulated in numerical models. At the same time, their underlying dynamics remain unclear. In this regard, they flow counter to the westward direction predicted by both Ekman and Sverdrup theory. Furthermore, they appear to be linked to the Leeuwin Current (LC) along the west coast of Australia and to larger-scale circulations , namely, the Indonesian Throughflow (ITF) and the Southern Ocean. Thus, the eastward flow represents a fundamental gap in our understanding of the large-scale mean flow in the SIO. 

This project will use analyses of in situ observations and numerical models to fill that gap. The observational analysis will rely on three main datasets.  Each dataset combines Argo data with historical data, the different mapping techniques resulting in products with characteristics suited to different aspects of the analysis: the CARS dataset developed at CSIRO is a high-quality monthly-mean dataset of T , S , and other water-mass properties, which allows for tracing watermasses; the IPRC dataset incorporates the additional product  of absolute dynamic topography, allowing an estimation of absolute geostrophic velocity; and the UTas dataset maps Argo and historical data on density surfaces, which will be useful in resolving finer frontal features and characterizing downwelling/upwelling regions. Satellite winds will be used to compute Ekman and Sverdrup flows and to force the models. To test specific hypotheses about the processes that control  the surface eastward currents, an ocean  circulation model will be used.

The research team combines the talents of scientists at the IPRC, CSIRO, and the University of Tasmania, with scientists at the latter institutions contributing their extensive knowledge of in situ observations in the SIO to the project
 
Broader Impact: Understanding the dynamics of these first-order features is necessary to validate and improve climate models. Moreover, these currents interact with the LC and the ITF, and are likely part of a basin-scale overturning circulation closed by downwelling within the LC and near the Antarctic Circumpolar Current. The dynamics of the surface eastward currents therefore should play an important role in SIO decadal variability. The results will likely apply to similar features in the other oceans.

por.por_cntn:
A remarkable aspect of the upper-ocean circulation in the tropical and subtropical South Indian Ocean (SIO) is the presence of near-surface, eastward flow across the basin, which often appears as a set of distinct currents and jets, such as the South Indian Countercurrent (SICC) and the Eastern Gyral Current (EGC). 

Despite the fact that these currents have been detected in observations and simulated in numerical models, their underlying dynamics remain unclear.  In this regard, they flow counter to the westward direction predicted by both basic ideas of ocean circulation (Ekman and Sverdrup theory).  Furthermore, they also occur in association with subsurface westward currents across the South Indian Ocean, and are linked to the Leeuwin Current (LC) and Leeuwin Undercurrent (LUC) along the west coast of Australia, as well as to large-scale circulations external to the SIO, namely, the Indonesian Throughflow (ITF) and to formation regions of Southern-Ocean (SO) modewaters (notably, Subantarctic Mode Water, SAMW).

Thus, lack of understanding about the SIO eastward flow represents a fundamental gap in our first-order understanding of the large-scale mean flow in the region. Our research has helped to fill this gap.  We have demonstrated that: 1) The shallow eastward flow across the SIO is driven primarily by the poleward increase of near-surface density.  2) The eastward flows separate into four branches: the EGC in the eastern, tropical SIO, which also appears to be linked to the ITF water; and three branches of the SICC, the southernmost of which is linked to Southern-Ocean modewaters. 3) Salinity forcing is essential for the generation of the EGC, as the EGC vanishes when salinity is neglected in geostrophic calculations.  4) Our modelling work identified two mechanisms for driving the southernmost SICC branch: the northwestward advection of Southern-Ocean modewater (SAMW) due to the northward bending of Rossby-wave characteristics; and the flow of Southern-Ocean water into the Indian Ocean due to a frictional (GM mixing) boundary region that joins the two oceans.  5) Water for the LC is supplied primarily by the shallow, eastward flow across the SIO (with secondary supplies from the Australian Northwest Shelf or directly from the ITF).  6)  A continental slope is required for the coastal trapping of the LC, the slope causing the offshore propagation of Rossby waves to have a strong southward component due to the topographic-β effect.

Our study has already had one application to other regions, namely, the interaction of the Southern Ocean with the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation. We also expect our LC results to have applications to other coastal regions as well.  Finally, the project has supported the intellectual development of several students and postdoctoral fellows.
